results.notes: Morphology: convex (slightly umbonate) striated cap with pellicle; off-white glossy stem with membranous annulus, staining grayish-brown after handling. Spore print: dark brown to black (?). Growth pattern: Solitary. Measurements: [n=1] cap 16.2 mm across by 6.4 mm high; stem 2.45 mm thick by 70.43 mm tall. Habitat: Beneath a fallen (likely) coniferous log in shaded sphagnum (moist not water-logged) within a miniature marshy valley in an upland sand-clay-rock and dried decayed wood mixed clearing surrounded by spruce forest residual.

results.notes: Morphology: bell-shaped cap slightly striated around margins with a more velvety surface and moistened slight umbo; white glossy stem staining yellowish. Spore print: brownish-black [very faint deposit (with possible contamination)]. Spores: elongated-ellipsoid, darker brownish [N=10] measure (11.8)11.9 – 12.4(13) × 6.2 – 6.4(6.9) µm; Me = 12.2 × 6.4 µm; Qe = 1.9. Growth pattern: solitary. Measurements: [n=1] cap 13.67 mm across by 7.45 mm high; stem 2.31 mm thick by 68.3 mm tall. Habitat: partly shaded moist open sphagnum within a miniature marshy valley in an otherwise upland sand-clay-rock and dried decayed wood mixed clearing surrounded by spruce forest residual.

results.notes: Morphology: acutely conic cap (occasionally campanulate with slight umbo) medium brownish, often white at around outer margin; whitish flexuous stem with major portion underlying substrate with thick root-like branches of mycelium. Spore Print: brownish-black. Spores: ellipsoid, brownish (10.5)11.3 – 12.8(13.4) × (6.4)6.7 – 7.8(8.1) µm; Me = 12.1 × 7.2 µm; Qe = 1.7. Growth pattern: scattered-gregarious, infrequent. Measurements: [n=3] cap 11.1-14.4 mm across by 10.0-11.0 mm high; stem 1.2-2.9 mm thick (widening towards base) by around 38.0-67.0 mm tall. Habitat: partly shaded fairly moist trailside from wood chips imbedded in black soil that is regularly flooded by stream overflow after an interval of heavy rain.

results.notes:
Date: 10/16/22; Time: 10:30am
Temp: 52°F; Humidity: 68%
White with a short (1-2cm) stalk leading to a “gill-less” mass with an irregular lumpy shape. Some look brain-like, with two hemispheres curling into a central line, while others are less symmetrical. Fine fluffy hyphae extend from the base of the stems. The mushrooms are growing in the dirt at the forest edge, 2-3 meters from a trail, amongst leaf litter and decaying logs. The dirt appears to have a high clay content.

results.notes:
I realize that “Agaricus haemorrhoidarius” is a now defunct name for our North American species, but this is the closest I could get to an ID. It’s a bit hard to key out because it was growing in grass clippings/leaf mulch from a nearby hospital campus, but it was in a beech forest that has quite old trees. There was some red staining, predominately on the stem of more mature specimens, but the staining upon bisection was very very subtle and limited mostly to the outer edges of the stipe’s interior. Smell is hard to pin down with these – it is not offensive to me like Xanthodermatai members I’m familiar with, but it’s not fragrant almonds like the arvenses / subrufescens I find in similar habitats. I guess I would describe the smell as mild mushroom + a subtle sweetness and complexity I can’t quite place. I don’t have Kerrigan’s book on the Agaricus yet, and I don’t have a microscope or chemicals yet – hoping to remedy that this winter :)

Edit: October 28th, 2022 – I went back today and they were fruiting again. This time they were fresh and weren’t waterlogged. The morphology was consistent and they still had the “bottle cap” type cap with the crimped edges and the almost completely flat cap. Smell is still mild and “clean” mushroomy smell. Some mild pink staining on the gill flesh and interior stipe like before, but a bit more strong this time around. I ordered KOH and applied it to the cap’s surface and the interior flesh and there was no significant reaction I could notice.

results.notes:
Growing on a wet rotting log in mature mixed hardwood forest. It was very warm and humid. I was walking this area of the Daniel Boone National Forest to see what all is growing and living there before it gets logged. Based on Forest Service maps of logging prescriptions, this area will have most of the canopy trees removed.

It was near the end of the day when I came to this log, and the light was getting low. I included one photo I took without flash to give you an idea of what it looked like in real life. I’d love to look at these in the dark sometime to see if they glow. In the dim forest light it seemed to have a greenish yellow glow. I’ve never seen anything like it before. They felt like firm gel. They were surprisingly tough, and did not smoosh apart when I tried to squish it between my fingers. No distinct smell, besides the general rotting log/fungi/forest smell.

I intend to go back when it gets warm again to see if these are still growing, but I have no idea if this spot will be the same when I go back, they might have it logged out by then. I can’t imagine that this fungus will continue to grow in sunny dry conditions that will be created through the logging. All of the descriptions I have read from other observers say it was growing in mesic habitat with shade. There are a lot of fungi and plants in this area that I only ever see in mature/old growth forests and I don’t expect them to survive the bulldozers, heavy machines and removal of the trees. In this area, these timber sales frequently convert the forest into red maple stump sprouts and invasive species.

If I ever see one of these again, I will put it in alcohol and send it to one of you all for analysis! I would love to know more about the species. There were lots of other fungi and slime molds around that day too. This is my first time on mushroom observer, and I’ll try to get more of the things I see on here if possible. I usually post on INat. This mushroom is on iNat here: https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/121501883

Info about the approved logging is here for anyone interested: https://www.kyheartwood.org/south-redbird-project.html

results.notes:
Growing on the insides and outsides of dead Phytolacca americana stems at the boundary between young hardwood forest and a parking lot. Some stems containing ant colonies. Co-occurring with Calpytella sp. DG2205071. Basidiocarps white (WHITE N 9.5 – 8.5 in Munsell); sessile to short-stipitate; with hairy margins and a smooth hymenium; 0.2 to 1.1 mm broad and 0.1 to 0.7 mm tall. Sclerotia absent. Not bioluminescent. Clamps present. Hairs thick-walled, encrusted, and with hyaline apices and brown bases in Melzer’s. Basidia clavate and 4-sterigmate. Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (13.7) 14.8 – 19.3 (20.6) × (6.7) 7 – 8.9 (9.3) µm; Q = (1.7) 1.8 – 2.4 (2.8); N = 30; Me = 16.9 × 8 µm; Qe = 2.1

results.notes:
Growing on the undersides of a Robinia pseudoacacia stick partially buried in hardwood leaf litter behind the Coker laboratory building. Co-occurring with Crepidotus sp. DG2206244. Basidiocarps sessile, pendent, cupulate, hairy and white. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Hairs cylindrical to slightly clavate, straight, and encrusted; basally clamped; some weakly dextrinoid. Hymenial cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate and basally clamped. Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6.2) 6.9 – 8.4 (9.2) × (4.6) 5.3 – 6.4 (6.9) µm; Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.48 (1.5); N = 30; Me = 7.7 × 5.8 µm; Qe = 1.3

results.notes:
A single large fruitbody growing on the southern bank of Coopers Rd., to the SE of Lebanon Lakes.
The overall morphology is that of sect. Validae and suggests either A. submaculata or A. canescens, both of which are found in the Pine Barrens habitat. Usually, I don’t have a problem discerning between these taxa, but this amanita sent me mixed signals. Since I left the mushroom in the same condition as I had found it, the subterranean morphology of the stipe is not known; neither is the odor of the fruitbody, which alone would have been of big help.
On 19-Sep-23 I changed the original ID from submaculata to canescens mostly because of the orangish color the UV remnants on the cap and the annulus edge.

results.notes:
Two collections (A & B labeled in photos) of several fruitbodies each growing 10-15 yards from each other in a very hostile environment — a sunlit grassy open space just to the north of the Tobyhanna Lake dam.
No staining noted. The odor was strong and reminiscent of the commercially available A. bisporus.
Both collections preserved as a single specimen, as they are presumed to be the same species.
The mature caps dropped spore and these will be measured for a more accurate determination to species. The choices in NA are A. andrewii, A. braendlei (=A. argenteum) & A. porphyrocephalus var. pallidus.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 1-Feb-24):
A full-length nrITS sequence of 659 bps was obtained from this collection by Steve Russell (ONT-nanopore). The RiC score is 183.
Top hits in the standard BLASTn-100 search at 99.24~99.34% similarity are 4 European accessions of Agaricus porphyrocephallus subsp. alpinus and 1 accession of Agaricus porphyrocephallus subsp. pallidus. The TYPE sequence of the latter species, NR_145000, is 99.1% similar. The EPITYPE sequence of Agaricus campestris, NR_151745, is only 97.3% similar.
A careful selection of relevant BLASTn accessions following trimming off the adjoining nrSSU & LSU fragments, gave rise to 2 ML-based trees in http://www.phylogeny.fr/simple_phylogeny.cgi (with G-blocks on and off), posted here as Fig. 1 & Fig. 2, respectively. The purpose of the G-blocks program is to “eliminate poorly aligned positions and divergent regions”. The two trees have almost identical overall topologies in terms of the clading of the accessions, as well as the inferred relationships between the species lineages (note that the branches can be pivoted at the nodes and the program automatically chooses how to pivot to give an optimal tree format). As can be seen in the annotated trees, the present sequences clades together with the accessions of A. porphyrocephalus subsp. pallidus within the highly supported A. porphyrocephalus complex, while the accessions of the related taxa A. andrewii, A. braendlei (=A. argenteum nom. illegit.) form their respective clades with a respectful statistical support.

results.notes:
Doesn’t have spines or pores under the scales. It just has a powdery substance, in clumps, underneath. This powder has a brown-violaceous tone, suspecting that the spore print is violaceous/brown
I think this is Thelephora, but this one has and odd shape. It has a steroid form, and was encrusting some rotten conifer wood, but at ground level, appearing terrestrial. (This are supposed to be ectomycorrhizal, right?) Absolutely no stem, or buried on the substrate, with the upper side like a bracket (see edited picture), and the spore bearing surface down, powdery but not pores.
The spores are brownish, angular, with lobes and warts or spines, irregular but elliptical, (7.7-10.0) x (5.6-7.3).
The basidia size and spore size seems to fit better Thelephora penicillata . Other possible candidates are T. terrestris (spores a bit larger, perhaps acceptable range) and T. anthocephala (usually on the ground).

results.notes: Growing in Taxus shrub needle duff and woodchips in an urban, landscaped setting. No other trees present in the immediate area. These smell strongly of almonds, though a bit less so than A. subrufescens – comparable to the smell of A. arvensis. Although the largest cap hadn’t even opened up completely, it was already 5+ inches in diameter so it would surely be on the upper threshold of the recorded cap size for the species. These displayed fairly prominent snakeskin/chevron ornamentation on the stipe for the species group – other friends have seen this feature apparently, but I’m not seeing a lot of it in obs on MO or iNat. Curious what this means for speciation or if its just normal morphological variability in the species/clade.

results.notes:
Gymnopilus ventricosus Group:
Very robust flush on heavily myceliated Alnus rubra(note the flattened/smooth tan bark beneath moss and bunched old succors near trunk base-lower left).
Delightfully sweet scent with this collection, akin to fruit loops cereal dry in the box.
All previous encounters I’ve had with Gymnopilus ventricosus have been on conifers(Douglas fir, Pinus and Spruce). Reports from collections on hardwoods have not ever turned out(yet) to be anything other than G. ventricosus here in Washington state. Perhaps this one is distinct/interesting. Perhaps not.
Annulus on all specimens is very thick/prominent and very high on stem. All stems ventricose.
Harvested 2 young(smaller) specimens for herbarium.

Spores: Ellipsoid-very large(larger than previous collections I’ve analyzed).

results.notes:
Fruiting beneath Sitka Spruce and Western Hemlock.
The spores/microscopy in this collection seem unusual in combination with physical features due to the fact that the disc on all specimens(in the field) appear reddish brown. Microscopy matches Leucocoprinus brebissonii, however. All collections I’ve previously encountered for Leucocoprinus brebissonii have been dark gray at disc/nearly black when young.
See my included microscopy of the smooth ellipsoid/narrowly ellipsoid spores WITH GERM PORE present. I puzzled over this collection based on macro field characteristics but after performing microscopy and then viewing the caps after dehydration(which are now completely gray and appear like standard dehydrated L. brebissonii). Perhaps the color variation is environmentally driven or this is a variety previously undescribed. Or I have missed something and there is a Lepiota, Leucocoprinus or Leucoagaricus with these combined features.
All Lepiotoid species with physical features matching this collection(like Lepiota cristata group for example) have very different bullet or triangular shaped spores. Any others with similar spore shape do not have germ pore present.
Odor: none detected.
Spore Print: white.
Spores: Ellipsoid with germ pore.
Bagged dehydrated specimens for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:
This tiny mushroom was growing singly (perhaps, see below) from the side of a very rotted conifer (likely larch) stump in a swamp.
The first photo is as found, the others as extracted from the stump for better access, all ambient-lit (in shade on a sunny morning).
The cap diameter is only about 3 mm across.
The dual coloration of the cap is presumably due to differential reflectance of blue sky (for which I have obviously not corrected).
Too small (for me) to examine well, but cap perhaps a bit wet or sticky based on debris.
Partial veil intact, so no spore print.
This is the same stump as in 472008 of Gymnopilus in 2021 and Gymnopilus was again present, though mostly on the opposite side of the stump.

results.notes: Morphology: Obtusely conic (grooved unevenly around) cap pale yellowish to buff when fresh, somewhat striated margins, rather slippery; white stem shiny, fibrose and rather flexible yet easily splits, stains dark golden-gray. Spore print: Purplish-brown. Spores: Ellipsoid, pale yellowish-brown; [N=20] measure (11.2)11.8 – 13(13.2) × (7.2)8.2 – 9.1(9.2) µm; Me = 12.4 × 8.5 µm; Qe = 1.5. Growth pattern: Scattered. Measurements: [n=2] cap 9.4-20.5 mm across by 6.4-13.1 mm high; stem 2.5-3 mm thick (gradually widening towards cap) by around 27-45 (42-88 including rhizomatous root that extends below surface) mm tall. Habitat: Partly sunny wood chips next to stream lined by sumac and goldenrod, growing amongst Psathyrella corrugis in clearing between trailside pine stand.

results.notes:
Specimens were sterile by the time I brought them home. I rehydrated them for several hours after they began to dehydrate and some ascospores developed in the asci, but based on their small size they must have been immature. I did not observe even the slightest suggestion of ridges that would point to C. venezuelae which is confirmed from Puerto Rico. The lack of spore ornamentation and their shape leads me to believe these are C. colensoi or an undescribed species. Mature spores of future collections should be more closely examined.

results.notes:
Terrestrial, probably decaying roots. Spores with a characteristic hollow cylindric apiculus that is sometimes oblique and an intercellular melleous pigment when dry or embedded in the thickened hymenium. Cystidia and inflated hyphae absent. 4-spored basidia common. Clamps present but not conspicuous at all septa.

results.notes:
The aftermath of the NJMA foray and ID session at SRP. This was the first time we collected there. The three consecutive images capture the entire ID table from left to right.
According to our recorder, John Burghard, we wound up collecting and identifying at least 122 taxa (some to genus only), including 40 species of gilled mushrooms, 15 species of boletes, 22 species of polypores, and 10 species of lichens.
This was the best 2022 foray of the season after NJMA forays began in late June. The hot and dry summer baked most of NJ to the crisp, but Gloucester Co., particularly its western half, was the only part of the state that had managed to receive normal to above normal precipitation throughout the summer months into September.

Spore Print: pinkish orange.(see image).
Spores: lemon shaped with side laying spores.
Face view spores: ovoid with curved apiculus like tips.
Dehydrated specimen and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.
